newsitem.title: INDONESIA: U.S. wants Indonesia to lead on financial services.
newsitem.headline: U.S. wants Indonesia to lead on financial services.

text.p: The United States said on Wednesday it wanted Indonesia to lead the deregulation of financial services in Southeast Asia under the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business and Agriculture Stuart Eizenstat said he had urged Indonesia's Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad and central bank governor Soedradjad Djiwandono to take up the initiative.

"We're hoping that Indonesia will take the same kind of leadership role in the financial services negotiations, which have twice failed, as it did in the information technology agreement (ITA)," Eizenstat said.

Eizenstat told a news conference the U.S. position was looked at with respect by Indonesian officials he met but there was still some resistance to ideas until people saw advantages and modified their opinions.
The next talks on the issue would be in September with the hope an agreement could be reached by December.
Indonesia would have to increasingly deregulate its financial services sector and bind this with WTO practices if it were to take up the leadership role the U.S. is urging, he said.
"We're willing to look for all the ASEAN countries for phased in liberalisation," he said.
The Association of South East Asian Nations groups Brunei, Burma, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.
"We have made an offer to immediately throw open our market to foreign competition at the earliest possible date," Eizenstat said.

"What we are looking for is reasonable time periods and reasonable market opening provisions so we can get a critical mass of countries as we did with the ITA....so trade will be more a two way street," he said.
Eizenstat said that as Indonesia sought to build a more sophisticated economy it needed a stronger financial sector.

"This will provide a stronger banking sector, it ought to be well regulated, but by having it increasingly open for insurance and for a variety of financial instruments it will support the increased domestic and foreign investment," he said.
